From these they have given our young State its teachers, scientists, agriculturists, engineers, doctors, dentists, architects, economists and administrators, all of a quality comparable to that provided in other countries far ahead of us in wealth and resources. What is really extraordinary about all this—but not surprising if we recall that the Irish have a certain genius for improvisation and that adverse odds call out the best side of the Irish character—is that so far our graduates can hold their own in any part of the world. That this is so the keen and constant demand for them from overseas is the best evidence.

I started this with the mention of Newman, who was the apostle of knowledge as its own end. It is to be feared that during the course of the speech I have lapsed from that ideal and have placed all the stress on the technological aspect of higher education. That was because I was thinking mostly in terms of our national survival and progress. Let me end, however, by quoting from the Report of the Committee on Australian Universities. I do not apologise for borrowing the extract, as it seems to me to be of universal application. The quotation reads:

“It is the function of the university to offer not merely a technical or specialist training but a full and true education, befitting a free man and the citizen of a free country. This is becoming harder, too, and the demands of a modern technical training use up so much time and energy on the part of both teachers and students that the wider ard more fundamental aims of a fully rounded education may seem sometimes to have fallen into the background. But it is important to the interests of the country, and of humanity, that they should not do so. It has been becoming more and more clearly and widely recognised of recent years that the world simply cannot afford that its highly soecialised professional men, technologists and scientists should not also be fully educated as rounded human beings. It sometimes seems that while we have been advancing at a formidable speed in our knowledge of technical matters, we have if anything been falling behind in our understanding and appreciation of human values. We can handle machines and physical nature beyond the dreams of previous generations, but we handle ourselves, our families and our fellow human beings in general no better, and perhaps less well, than our fathers did before us. Many of the most serious problems in the world to-day are moral problems and are problems of human relationship. The need for the study of humanities is therefore greater and not less than in the past.”

Speaker.P: I offer my congratulations to the Minister on his comprehensive contribution of a character not usually associated with a Supplementary Estimate of £10. In special circumstances, we overlook that idiosyncrasy and gladly confine ourselves to congratulating him on a justifiable marathon.
It is important, before I deal with other matters, that we come to the heart of this matter at once and so I recall what the Minister said in the course of his speech:

Of this sum of £250,000 the College agreed to find £100,000, and the first step towards finding the remainder is the present motion asking for a token amount for the purpose and the ratifying thereby by Dáil Éireann of the Government's agreement in principle, as already announced, to the transfer to the Belfield site.

MainHeading.P: I want to say on behalf of the Fine Gael Party that we approve that decision. This whole matter of the building of an adequate University College, Dublin, appears to be one of those questions which has, in my judgment, become unnecessarily clouded by furious acrimony when, as I see it, none is necessary at all. As the report of the Commission presided over by Mr. Justice Ó Dálaigh records, members of that Commission themselves saw more than one possibility and at one stage of their deliberations leant towards the aim of erecting the necessary buildings in or around the existing Earlsfort Terrace site. It was only after protracted inquiry and anxious thought that they came to the conclusion that that simply was not a practical policy, for the reasons set out in greater detail by their reports. Then they came to the conclusion that if the unity of the University College were to be maintained, the transfer to the new site at Belfield was essential and that in the existing circumstances the best site is the site available at Belfield.

I apprehend that I may draw down upon my head the furious acrimony of both right and left if I point out to those who are now bitterly opposed to the proposed transfer that their position is fully understood and that everybody interested in this matter has a certain sympathy with their point of view. The College authorities themselves at an early stage sought to extend the Earlsfort Terrace premises to a degree that would make provision for all that was anticipated as being necessary in the future. They turned with reluctance from the hope of achieving that end. The people, and they are responsible people, who signed this report of the Ó Dálaigh Commission, also felt great sympathy with those who would wish to keep the premises in or about St. Stephen's Green and Earlsfort Terrace but they also, after a study of the facts, were persuaded that the thing was not possible and so recommended Belfield to us.

I would urge on those who feel passionately that that conclusion should not have been reached that they should not recklessly charge everybody who has been convinced of the necessity of transferring the University to Belfield of bad faith, of folly and of worse. All we are doing is trying to do our best and to arrive at the right conclusion. I would also say to certain people who resent the intrusion of Tuairim and other interested parties in this controversy, not to condemn such public-spirited persons as nothing but “nosey-parkers” and mischief makers. They have a right to their view, too. I do not agree with the view that it is now practicable or desirable to locate the new University College in or around Earlsfort Terrace. I do not think it is practicable or desirable. I never did. In that, perhaps, I differ from others. It is important to make up our minds that it is neither practicable nor desirable. If it is either impracticable or undesirable, then we should not attempt to do it.

In that connection, Sir, it is right to remind the House that in the trials and tribulations of human life only too often do we discover by bitter experience that the best is not infrequently the enemy of the good.

If we are never to do anything until we are certain that we have reached the apotheosis of perfection that, I suggest, is the classic “philosophe du complet” which ends in nobody doing anything at all because he makes up his mind that it is unworthy of him to put his hand to anything which is not the closest, which is not, in fact, an absolute approximation to the omniscience and omnipotence of God, which is given to none of us. Therefore, the best we can do is to come as near the ideal as we can, and the essence of common sense is to discover clearly the distinction between the practical approximation to the highest perfection and the impracticable fatuity of arguing oneself into incapacity for any kind of action at all. I am quite satisfied that argument has been carried as far as it is now desirable to do, and our Party is prepared to support the principle referred to in the paragraph which I have quoted from the Minister's speech.

There are certain matters mentioned by the Minister in the course of his observations to which I shall now refer though I am not prepared, nor could I reasonably be expected to be prepared for as wide a discussion as would be suggested by the Minister's speech. I am making no reflection whatever on the administration of the Rules of Order but, if I attempted to make a speech like that on a Supplementary Estimate for £10, pandemonium would have broken out in which my long experience of proceedural matters would have been tested to save my skin. However, I do not propose to pursue that line of thought but I would like to turn to page 2 and to read the modern gloss on a story of which I have some knowledge. The Minister stated:
In 1909-10 University College, Dublin's student total was 530. At that time it was thought that the maximum number of students would never exceed 1,000...

I can assure the Minister he is labouring under a pathetic illusion if he accepts any such fallacious belief but the men of that day had learned the bitter lesson that in this troubled world, and in the much more troubled world they were working in, they had to reconcile themselves not infrequently to seeking, not even the second best, but to rejoice when their efforts achieved for our people the second worst.

They were fighting then to get our people the right to higher education and they got it and they had no apprehension there would flow from their efforts and those that came after them the opportunity we now have to expand what they set on foot to meet the needs of our people. It was their confidence 50 years ago in the capacity and prospects of our people that put us all where we are to-day. I only hope this generation to which we belong will be worthy of that generation that went before them and, with the same confidence and the same hope for the future of this country, will provide now for the expansion which they foresaw but which they were not in a position fully to attain because they were pleading the cause of higher education in Ireland, not in Dáil Éireann, but in the British House of Commons.
I hope that we in our own Parliament will be able to do as well for our children, and our children's children, as they in the foreign Parliament were able to do for us who are here.

I do not want to seem critical of the Minister for he was critical of himself in his concluding paragraph, but I did feel that there was something of desecration in beginning with the lofty thought of Newman and then treading so dusty and dreary a technological path as he condemned us to follow. But, I understand his problem, and suffice it to say that while I welcome his recourse to the Antipodes for a peroration I would have thought the Minister for Education might have found in Newman's own work a suitable conclusion to his observations. I shall content myself by saying that I would have had more interest in a peroration from Newman than what he gave us but if that is the best the Minister could do I am glad he gave us that, rather than abandon us in the forest of technological matter through which he led us in the course of his address.
At one stage the Minister stated:

If I may digress here for a moment, I should also like to inform the House that, despite criticisms one hears from time to time of the situation in our secondary schools, 89 per cent. of our recognised secondary teachers are University graduates...

Would he permit me to digress for a moment to ask him while that statistic may be true, what help is it that secondary teachers should have a Degree in Commerce and be teaching Greek? Perhaps if the Minister would look into that he could give us greater reassurance than merely by the process of counting heads? Perhaps if he would inquire, when he comes to deplore the scarcity of secondary teachers, whether his problem might not be greatly relieved if he would waive his present requirements that every secondary teacher in Ireland must satisfy his Department that he is capable of teaching through the medium of Irish.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: What is wrong with that?
In the name of common sense why do you want to insist on a man being able to teach through Irish when the children in the school do not know it?
The standard up to now has been very good, if not the best.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: Do not start that game now. That started in 1909 too—the question, of Irish in the National University. We know all about it.

A regulation requiring teachers in secondary schools to go through what is the present farce of persuading the Department of Education he is capable of teaching through the medium of Irish is an outrage on honesty and decency.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: What is wrong with it?
It is a farce.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: The Deputy only thinks so.

Of the teachers who go through that farce 50 per cent. of them could pretend to be proficient and not ten per cent. of them are competent to teach through the medium of Irish with the same competency that they could teach through their own vernacular.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: How does the Deputy know that?
Common sense.
I trust the Parliamentary Secretary will intervene in this discussion but, in the interval, I think it is not proper for him and me to indulge in a discussion across the floor of the House.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: Fag é sin. Nil aon baint ag sin leis an cheist.
I think disorderly interventions in Irish may make more trouble.
The Chair feels that matter could be more relevantly discussed on the main Estimate.

So do I but 90 per cent. of the Minister's speech could be more relevantly discussed on the main Estimate. If the Parliamentary Secretary could be persuaded to set a better example for his cohorts, I submit to the Chair.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: I submit Deputy Dillon was disorderly, was completely out of order in dragging in this.
The Minister went on to say:

MainHeading.P: Moreover, it is the penalty of our graduates' unrestricted access to Britain and virtually unrestricted access to the United States and Canada and to the high remuneration there that if we are to have a sufficiency of doctors and engineers for ourselves we must produce more doctors and engineers than we can absorb.
This seems to me to be the language of insanity.

How is it a penalty on our people to be free to go where they want to go and to be welcome wherever they want to go so long as there is no compulsion upon any of us to go? How can any rational being describe it as a penalty upon us that we have free access to Great Britain and virtually free access to the United States and Canada, where the remuneration is so high that if we are to have a sufficiency of doctors and engineers for ourselves that we must produce more doctors and engineers than they could absorb? Is this not going to extremes of chauvinistic insanity? What is the purpose of a university? Is it not to provide higher education for our children? What is the purpose of a man's life? Is it not to use the faculties God gave him to the greatest honour and glory of God wherever he can?

Speaker.hpid: Major de Valera Major de Valera
Speaker.P: And to save his soul.

I am talking of what our aim should be to enable our children to do. It is one of the purposes of the university to give them access to knowledge, to expand and give them an opportunity of developing the faculties God gave them for the purpose of using them to the best possible advantage, and also, as Deputy Vivion de Valera said, to save their souls to the honour and glory of God. But surely a student going into a University is the primary consideration? They are not fodder in any chauvinistic or nationalistic view. There is no reflection on a man if he believes he can use his faculties abroad better, if he goes where he can best use them. It is greatly to be rejoiced at if more of our own graduates find an opportunity to use the gifts with which they have been endowed in this country but it is not a subject of lamentation and not a grievous penalty that the world is open to them wherever they want to go.

There is not a country in Europe that would not give its right hand to be able to describe as its infinite good fortune what the Minister for Education pleases to describe—I take it in a distracted moment—as a penalty under which our people labour. I have made reference to the statement that science graduates everywhere are not inclined to teach, that there are greater opportunities in industry. It does not make their prospects any more glittering to them if they have to go through the pretence that they are able to teach through the medium of Irish.

Speaker.hpid: Donnchadh Ó Briain Donnchadh Ó Briain
Speaker.P: What is wrong with that?

Speaker.hpid: Mr. T. Lynch Mr. T. Lynch
Speaker.P: What is right with it?

Do not rouse him. The Parliamentary Secretary must not fall into the heresy of believing he can carry conviction to any part of this House by growing red and angry and saying: “What is wrong with that”.
The matter is not one for discussion on this Estimate. It is a detail that will arise on the main Estimate.

With respect, Sir, the Minister dealt with it at considerable length. I sympathise with the Minister in having to envisage all possibilities but it causes me some twinge of anxiety to hear an Irish Minister for Education say that we had too many University students. Can there be such a thing as too many students provided we are certain that all of them are capable of benefiting from higher education? I do not think the case has ever been made that we are putting into the Universities of this country a miscellaneous bunch of unqualified undergraduates. I have heard those allegations made about certain State Universities in the United States, that the preliminary sifting of material is not adequate and the result is, you have a not inconsiderable number who really get no benefit at all. But here, if anything, the matriculation standards, certainly of the National University of Ireland, are of a very exacting character.

In those circumstances can we contemplate the possibility of our having too many undergraduates? I think not. I think the process of sifting here is, if anything, too rigorous and I gather that the Minister himself feels this is so. This is a subject with which I have the deepest sympathy, that the time is overdue when we should be able to make it true in, this country that the child of any parents who are poor, if he has the capacity to benefit from a University education, should have the course laid open to him by a suitable system of scholarships and endowments where the resources of the parents would otherwise forbid access to the University for him. So that I take it that that phrase the Minister used may be regarded as a momentary aberration on the part of the Minister. In our circumstances I cannot conceive of the contingency he envisages arising.

MainHeading.P: The Minister then went on to deal with a matter which I think is very relevant to our deliberations on the fundamental issue involved in this Supplementary Estimate. He spoke of the fact that there is room for the erection of halls of residence, and some residential accommodation is generally desirable in or close to the University, which is a feature of University life. That is an extract from the Commissioners' Report. The Minister said, I should add, that it was not the intention of the Government that halls of residence should be supplied by State aid. Why? Why does the Minister exclude that possibility categorically? I think there would be a very considerable lessening of apprehension on the part of many of those who doubt the wisdom of the Belfield project if it were made abundantly clear that there was an early prospect of residential accommodation for students in the University or in hostels on or adjacent to the campus. Why should that not be a legitimate part of the whole scheme?

We might consider whether hostels should be run by the University as the residential colleges of Oxford and Cambridge are run or the residential part of Trinity College, Dublin is operated, or we could consider circumstances whereby hostels would be run by religious for the accommodation of young men and young women in suitable premises as has been the custom in U.C.D. to which quite a number of such hostels are attached. But why should there not be the possibility, if it were thought desirable, of the Government giving some advances for the construction of such hostels, if and when it was possible to find sites for them on or adjoining the campus? I believe the campus is of such dimensions that it is not at all impossible that room could be found upon it for suitable hostels. If they are to form part of the general building complex and of the architectural scheme envisaged I do not see why we could not at least consider assisting suitable bodies to erect them.

I am told that if the existing hostels that we have had had to bear the capital cost of building they would have been closed down long ago. Most of them have been provided by gift, or bequest, of one kind or another, and their operating costs correspond pretty closely with the income they are able to collect from the students. Therefore. if we anticipate providing adequate residential facilities for those who need them—that is to say, students coming from some distance or students having no friends or relatives in the city with whom they can live—it may be impossible to get the necessary hostels erected unless the possibility of State aid is envisaged. I would urge the Minister carefully to consider that matter before a final and irrevocable decision is taken upon it.

That is all I have to say about this project. I wish it well. I hope it will be a success. I am quite convinced it will be. But I make this most earnest appeal: there is no project, however admirable, which is not in some degree stultified if it is born in an atmosphere of raging acrimony. There is room for differences of opinion here, but it will be to the interests of every aspect of this problem if those who differ will agree to differ, freely conceding, one to the other, that, having examined the problem with the best wit that we individually and severally possess, we have come to our conclusions with the largest measure of honesty we are in a position to command. I do not think the opponents of this scheme are actuated by malice or an evil desire to frustrate. I think they have just come to the wrong conclusion and I am prepared to say that I am not satisfied that they have always had the patience to examine home every aspect of the problem on which they have publicly expressed a view.

I fully appreciate that they may charge against me and those who think with me a similar fault. All I can say is that I have talked as much as have most Deputies about it, with those who agree with me and to those who disagree with me. I have read the reports; I am fully conscious of the fallibility of people who write reports, which, by their bulk and dullness, are almost unreadable, and people who write reports which, by their colour, format and style, are almost like a best seller, or who write reports which are delightfully illustrated but not always convincing. I have read them all and tried to give them value. All I can protest is that I, and my colleagues who agree with me, have reached our conclusions not without careful and deliberate thought.

Speaker.P: No little word about the rural areas.
Letterkenny, for-instance.

I have no doubt that when Deputy O'Malley comes to deal with these matters he will be reminded of the narrow relevance of the Supplementary Estimate, as was pointed out earlier by the Leas-Cheann Comhairle to-day. If these perilous paths are to be attempted I will leave the intrepid adventure to the Deputy. I have already bearded the lion once in his den, and only a foolish man would attempt to do that twice on the one day.

One last word to the Minister: courage. In 1909 and in 1910 they did not tell the British Government that they hoped to have it in 25 years; they said, “We want it now.” They got it. We have not to make that stipulation on any foreign authority. If I had to choose between buying secondhand machinery from abroad to equip an activity, the output of which is highly problematical, and finding the capital to provide University education under tolerable conditions for a half of the student body of Ireland, I would choose the University. I think it will be a great reflection on the country if we cannot put this through in ten years at the outside. I deplore the suggestion that it will take 25 years.
Twenty years.
Twenty is just as bad.
Agreed.

In one sense, it will take forever because the future is a long thing. It would be a deplorable thing if we should ever contemplate standing still. In that sense the extension of the educational opportunities of our people is a task forever but, in the strictly limited job we have to do here of building University College, Dublin, on the campus at the Belfield site, I should like to think I would see it finished. I should like to think that as the oldest undergraduate, perhaps, of that institution I would be given the opportunity of sauntering through its leafy bowers, and rejoicing in a work well done.

It must, indeed, be very dull for anyone to listen to me after the flow of oratory we have just heard from Deputy Dillon. Perhaps the Minister will bear in mind that he would make an excellent Professor of Romance Languages or of English Literature. Anyone coming in here to-day would not know that this was the National Assembly, the general tenor of the debate has been so high —unfortunately.

MainHeading.P: At the outset I should like to refer to a matter introduced by Deputy Dillon. He referred to the Irish language. I do not intend to dwell very long on the subject, but my comments have a bearing on the Estimate before the House.

Speaker.P: The Chair feels it would be more appropriate on the main Estimate. It is a detail that does not relevantly arise on the Supplementary Estimate.

I appreciate that. I respectfully submit, however, that the point I wish to make has some relevance. Under the first Chancellor of the University in the summer of 1910 the eagerly awaited decision was taken to make the Irish language and literature obligatory at matriculation on all students of Irish domicile. That regulation took effect in 1913. Deputy Dillon cannot quote Scripture to suit his own purposes all the time. On the one hand he praises the men who went before the present Senate of University College.
Little the Deputy knows whom I was praising, but there are many here who do know.
I would point out to the House that the foundation of the National University was based on love of the language and love of Irish culture.
I was learning the language before the Deputy was born.

I have no doubt the Deputy was and I hope he appreciates it as I do at my age. I disagree with the Minister when he says that this project should take twenty years but I should have prefaced my remarks by congratulating him on making such a lengthy speech without taking even a drink of water. I know that he has gone to a great deal of trouble in this matter and that he appreciates the seriousness of the position of University education in this country, which, in my humble opinion, is in an appalling state.

MainHeading.P: May I say to the Minister that I do not think he was being completely honest with the House when he mentioned that period of 20 years? Why did he not say that it was all a question of finance? If it is a question of finance he should let us know and if it is not a question of finance I cannot see how it could take 20 years to complete the proposal. Such a statement is a reflection on the capabilities of the engineering and building professions in the country. It should not tax our ingenuity to spend seven million pounds in four years.

I would say to the Minister that he cannot expect the Irish taxpayer to bear this entire burden. We are at present possibly taxed to the limit of our capabilities and I think that we should utilise our borrowing powers to get the money from the World Bank, of which we became a member some years ago. The repayments to the World Bank would be far lighter than if we attempted to raise all this capital from the Irish people.

I think the most serious aspect of the reports is this question of the 20 years' period. Suppose we accept that principle, let us see where we will be as far as University College Dublin is concerned in 1965. We have it beyond yea or nay, on the evidence of the various Professors who appeared before the Commission, that this is a question of the most extreme urgency, that the present situation is a critical one. The only immediate action proposed to be taken is that we give a grant forthwith of £250,000 on the recommendation of an inter-Departmental Committee subject to the College authorities raising £100,000 from their own resources. That grant deals only with the Faculty of Science. What is going to happen in the meantime?

I do not think that there is anyone in the country who studied the project and read the report of the Commission who will not agree that the only decision left to the Government was to build at Belfield. When a Government sets up a Commission, it is not necessarily bound to accept the findings of that Commission but anyone can see that to depart from the recommendations of the Commission in this case would be a complete waste of time. Why go to a solicitor and pay him for advice if you have made up your own mind beforehand? A lot of people do that and get a kick out of it.

Speaker.P: They generally get more than a kick out of it.

I was one of the people who urged that an amalgamation should take place between University College, Dublin and Trinity College, Dublin. I advocated that at a symposium in the Shelbourne Hotel and I was castigated over it and misquoted by the Revd. Alfred O'Rahilly. Not alone did he misquote me in the publication called Hibernia but he took my words out of their context and gave them a completely different meaning so as to change completely what I had said. He ended up by pointing out the danger of the line of thinking of certain politicians of the present day.
Is this relevant to the matter before the House?

It is relevant to the Minority Report. I advocated a tie up between University College, Dublin and Trinity College subject to religious guarantees being given to the satisfaction of the heads of both religious denominations. The position of the National University is that it is a Catholic University. I know that some members of this House, before this debate is over, will have a crack at the Bishops and also at the views of other speakers in this House. I have had many a crack at the Bishops myself but not on questions of faith or morals, not that my morals are above reproach. Those were matters of a semi-political nature however.

MainHeading.P: I do accept the fact that, in regard to such matters as education, the Bishops of the Catholic Church have every right to put forward their views and I shall accept without reservation their recommendations. I am bound to do that. This, then, is the Catholic University of Ireland which we are discussing tonight.

I think Deputy Dillon misinterpreted an extract from the Minister's speech. Unfortunately, I have not a copy of the speech before me. He adduced that the Minister meant that it was a penalty on certain of our children who qualify at college to have to emigrate. Was that the suggestion of the Deputy?—that the word “penalty” should not have been used by the Minister, that, in fact, it was not a penalty?

Speaker.P: They have the right to go anywhere.

The right to go anywhere. My interpretation of the Minister's statement was that the penalty was that the Irish taxpayer was paying for the export of graduates from this country to foreign lands —in order words, that we are subsidising work which could well be done in Canada, Australia and other lands. I quite agree with the point the Minister made. He said that there are instances of graduates going abroad to get post-graduate experience and returning to this country, and that the country reaps the benefit of their specialised knowledge in certain instances.

It would be impossible in the short time at our disposal to go into all this. The House should be given a week to discuss this Supplementary Estimate. In my humble opinion it is the most important Estimate to come before the House for many a long year. There are many aspects of the Estimate. It is difficult to speak without having a copy of the Minister's speech. There are some sentences that one would have to read five or six times to see where the comma was. “All the charms of all the Muses often flowering in a lonely word.”

MainHeading.P: The Minister did not make any reference to one matter and he may do so in replying. I want to know if remuneration or allowances are a matter for the Senate of the National University. Great play is made of the interpretation of the term “allowance”. However, Deputies have now been made the guinea pigs in that matter and it may be used elsewhere. The Minister might refer to the question whether it is the Senate that fixes the remuneration or salaries of the professors and lecturers because, unless these salaries are stepped up very greatly, unless the leaders of the respective professions and the Deans of the Faculties are paid a proper salary befitting their office, I am afraid we shall not continue to get the best type of person.

For some peculiar reason best known to himself, the Minister made no reference to the College of Surgeons and other institutions of that nature where some citizens qualify in certain professions. The Minister referred to the number of graduates in Medicine. Were those figures in respect of the National University alone or did they include all graduates in the State?

The Minister expressed the sentiment, which was endorsed by Deputy Dillon, that every child in this country should have an opportunity of University education. That, of course, is “a consummation devoutly to be wished” but there again we must be practical. I have not heard the Minister or Deputy Dillon say how that could be achieved. I certainly have no solution. We are told that every child who goes to the University costs the taxpayer £400 to £500. We taxpayers—taxpayers from the 1st of next month—will be paying £400 to £500 for every student in a University. It has been calculated by the excellent body, the Tuairm sub-committee, that with the building of Belfield that could be put at £1,000 per head, to be borne by the taxpayer. Therefore, it is only wishful thinking at the present time to suggest that every child who wishes to go to a University should be able to do so. I do not think that that could be possible even if the scholarship limits were widened. For instance, at present many brilliant children cannot go to a University because some local authority, in its wisdom, decides by nine votes to eight that they will give only six scholarships instead of eight as the rates are too high.

That problem must be tackled very quickly. Is it wise to tackle it quickly if it means increasing the numbers coming to Dublin? It will take 20 years to build Belfield. What am I leading up to? I have said that it will take 20 years to build Belfield and that an extension of the scholarship scheme may increase the numbers going to University College, Dublin. I am told that the number at University College, Galway, is static but that Cork is on the increase. Where is the Minister's solution? We are told that Earlsfort Terrace is like a sardine tin, that no more can be fitted in. What will happen in the next five years? Does the Minister not feel in his heart that there is a little outpost of civilisation—Urbs antiqua fuit studiisque asperima belli—an ancient city versed in the arts of war and learning— where, indeed, a university existed long before any of those that we are discussing today was established, in Mungret College, as Deputy Dillon knows, or should know?

Speaker.P: I hope the Deputy is not suggesting I am an alumnus of that institution, respectable an establishment as it undoubtedly is.

I must compliment the Minister for investigating the whole position of University education. However, it is a great pity that when the Government were setting up the 1957 Commission on University Education the terms of reference were not wider. I do not think anyone else seems to agree with that idea but perhaps the Minister when he is replying will give more details as to what the terms of reference will be in respect of this Commission on University Education which the Government have decided to set up.

MainHeading.P: This is not the time or the place to speak about the claims of Limerick to a University. The Minister has cut the ground from under me and, I suppose, my colleague Deputy Russell by announcing the setting up of this Commission. I have no doubt that if I go into detail on the claims of Limerick to a University on this Supplementary Estimate you. Sir, would suggest that in due course I should appear before the said commission and propagate my views there. However, there are other places such as Waterford; they need a University there, maybe.

I think both the Minister and Deputy Dillon are incorrect in their references to residential accommodation. The Minister might say in reply that the lay-out plan shows hostels or the “campus” as Deputy Dillon calls them. I do not know why there is no residential accommodation. The Minister was quoting Newman. There is another quotation I could give from Newman to the effect that a University is not a University unless it is residential. That is what he hoped for and that is what he aimed at eventually in Ireland.

Where will the 5,000 students live? Supposing 3,000 of them are living elsewhere, does the Minister think the other 2,000 can live in digs around the Ballsbridge area? According to an American congress man that was supposed to be growing into a slum. Where are these students supposed to live? If you have a railway station you have trains; if you have a greyhound track you have hares; if you have a publichouse you have beer; if you have a University you should have accommodation. I hate the word “hostel”; I hate the word “campus” too. The word “hostel” should be “struck from the record.” The impression I have is that a hostel is a kind of nissen hut where you make tea on a primus stove.

We should have a University with proper residential accommodation. One would expect that would be possible with an expenditure of £7 million or whatever the cost will be. I had hoped we would have got a breakdown of this figure. I should like a ruling from you on this. The Minister is seeking only £10 to-day but we are dealing with an expenditure of £7,000,000. Will the Minister be coming back with an itemised account of the expenditure in due course? Are we to-day voting a sum of £10 or £7 million? I would appreciate a ruling from you on that. I want to know, before we decide on this, whether we will be given the breakdown of the expenditure of this sum which, in my opinion, is a very reasonable thing for this House to ask the Minister in respect of such a colossal amount of money.

MainHeading.P: The Minister referred very briefly to the claims of University College, Cork and University College Galway. The requirements of U.C.G. were put forward by Monsignor de Brun, Professor Mitchell and the other members of the governing body in U.C.G. Professor Atkins and members of his staff gave evidence about the requirements of University College, Cork and the financial implications involved in those requirements. Are we giving the Universities that money in toto? Are we giving U.C.D. and the other Universities all their requirements or are we going to cut down on their requirements? If so, we should like to know how much and also why.

The Minister refers to the fact that it is very difficult to limit or control the admission of students to faculties. I cannot see why. The Minister's suggestion, I think, is that if a student passes his matriculation he should be entitled to go on for any faculty of his choosing. That is reading too much into the Constitution and protecting the free will of our citizens a bit too much. What about protecting the taxpayer for a change? The Minister tells us that fifty per cent. of the doctors and engineers emigrate. Is every taxpayer to continue, when Belfield is built, to contribute £1,000 for every student who wants to be a doctor or engineer? We are exporting fifty per cent of those to Canada, Britain or the United States.

I am 100 per cent. with Deputy Dillon when he says that it is a great thing to educate our children and that if emigration is inevitable and if we have the type of people who will emigrate in any case we should not send our young people out as serfs, slaves or lackeys but as educated people with a Degree that will enable them to earn their living.

I think it only reasonable that the Minister should interfere in this question and express his views which I am sure will be respected by the Senate of the National University. The Senate have acted before in this regard. In certain instances they have said that there are only say, 52, vacancies in engineering and the first 52 are taken—either on Leaving Certificate or the College Entrance and they get the places. Surely we can control admission to the Medical School and the Engineering School? If we export 50 per cent. of our graduates surely it would be reasonable to say we must cut down the numbers admitted by say 25 per cent. That would not be asking too much. I think a direction could be given.

The Minister did not make—and this is a very important point, in my opinion—any reference to any change or possible change in the 1908 Universities Act or the Charter of the University nor did he say that it was proposed to make any change. I could understand it if the Minister said that he was making that question one of the terms of reference of the commission which he proposes to set up but I do not want to leave this matter and then find that because the Charter is framed as it is that the possible setting up of a University in Limerick or of certain faculties would be frustrated because of the failure to change either the Charter or the 1908 Act. Perhaps the Minister would let us have some information on that point.

Again, the Minister has not said if he proposes any changes in the Senate or in the method of administration of the National University at present or in the future. Whoever pays the piper should be able to call the tune. I am not suggesting State intervention; I am not a Socialist, although, perhaps, I may have some Socialist leanings, on Social Welfare and Health, but I seriously think the representation of the State at present on the Senate of the National University is inadequate. If I am correct the Government nominates only four members. I am very glad that representation of the Universities has been continued in the Seanad.

Speaker.P: Restored.

Restored, continued and abolished. While University representatives might be able to put the University point of view and while they might put down motions of interest and help to the University that would also be of assistance to the elected members of the House, I still think that the Government should have greater representation. If you look up the attendances at the meetings of the Senate you will see very interesting figures.

Not everyone can attend these long-drawn-out meetings. Persons may be interested only in one or two specific matters relating to their own sphere of activity or points that they might be interested in on behalf of the Government or on behalf of the Minister for Education so as to advise him on certain aspects—I do not know. I think one solution would be to give each of the Governing Bodies more power, as I advocated for the Department of Social Welfare—the analogy is a bit strained—to give the local officer of Social Welfare discretionary power. I think the Governing Bodies of the Constituent Colleges in Cork and Galway—I do not know about Maynooth; perhaps it would be in a different position—should control their own affairs rather than have them coming up here and being outvoted, possibly, by vested interests or people with more representation.

I could speak very strongly about the National University but I do not want to abuse my privileges here. I was not very satisfied about the Visiting Commission. What happened about that? Surely that is all part and parcel of this Estimate. I never fully understood what it was about and I do not know whether they found any injustices, inaccuracies or anomalies or— to put it crudely—anything “hookey”. I saw some report in the papers, in the Irish Times and the Irish Press the other day, to the effect that this commission's report was in the hands of the Government. It specifically referred to the appointments of certain professors and lecturers.

MainHeading.P: I think I have made my point sufficiently. The State should have more representation on the Governing Bodies and on the Senate of the National University itself; as composed at present, I think that body is completely unwieldy. I have no doubt that there are some of the most eminent men in the country on the Senate of the National University; most of the professors and lecturers in the various Constituent Colleges are outstanding men but you have some peculiar characters—we have them here also— and most eccentric people as well.

Before I speak, I understand that Deputy Blowick reported progress when this matter was being debated previously. Am I in order in speaking now or does Deputy Blowick wish to speak?

I had not concluded on the last occasion when dealing with the question of closing hours. Without any acrimony, the case I put to the Minister is that it seems the whole body of opinion throughout the country, with the exception of the Minister and members of the Government apparently, is directly opposed to the proposal in the Bill. When the bulk of opinion is directly opposed to it, I think the Minister is unwise in pushing it. Apparently the trade themselves are not in favour of it. Not a single representation has been made to me or to any other Deputy I know of in favour of the Minister's proposal. The Minister would be wise to leave the hours exactly as they are. I do not want to introduce any note of bitterness but one must take notice of public opinion, especially when the public take the trouble of bringing their opposition to this measure to the notice of Deputies.

Some Deputy described certain sections of the people as pressure groups and so on. On second thoughts I decided to pass that over. In my opinion, it was an ignorant and uninformed remark and it certainly was not fair comment on the matter. The Minister would be wise to yield to public opinion on this occasion. The Minister has not made a case for it himself. Nobody I heard made a case for it. Definitely there is no demand for it up and down the country, either by the licensed trade themselves or their customers. Everyone is satisfied with the present hours and the Minister would be wise in meeting the public demand.

One of the very purposes of this House is to make laws that suit the people. Only a foreign Government in occupation of the country would deliberately try and impose their will in complete violation of the wishes of the people. The reason the Minister himself has been sent here is to do the things the people want. Definitely some reform of the licensing laws was necessary. In the section of the Bill with which we are dealing the Minister is outraging public opinion. He is taking a foolish step, a step that has not been asked for by any section of the people concerned. While I would be very sorry to introduce anything like bitterness, politics and so on, the Minister would be wise, I think, to meet the wishes of the people.

MainHeading.P: I know that one of the Minister's answers will be that the Commission set up to inquire into the matter has recommended this proposal. Might I respectfully submit two points on that? First, while they may have had reasons at the time, about three years have elapsed since the Commission met and made their recommendations. The second is that no matter what the Commission recommended at that time public opinion is now very emphatic on the point that the Minister's proposals are not the correct ones.

Speaker.P: I rise in support of the amendment I have tabled on this Bill. In plain words, it proposes that the closing hour be 11.30 in Dublin county and the rural areas. I am proposing that because it is and has been the general custom in the country for people who want a late evening's drinking to avail of the facilities of the 12 o'clock midnight closing hour. I have been impressed very much by the case made by Deputy Blowick. This seems to be a most unpopular Bill. It seems to please nobody. The alteration in the hours appears to threaten and upset the trade. The total abstinence associations have written thousands of letters to their Deputies complaining that they dislike the Bill. Church leaders have spoken out against the proposed alterations contained in the Bill. It has been opposed very vigorously by a substantial number of the publicans and is also opposed by the staffs working in these licensed premises. In addition to all those interests, the general public, who are interested in the facilities available under the licensing laws, are also not satisfied with the proposals in the Bill.

I consider that these proposals will not improve the existing arrangement. That is the very point made by Deputy Blowick. Generally speaking, the existing arrangement in regard to the closing hours of licensed premises has worked well and has proved to be satisfactory. Of course, there will be cranks who will speak long and loud in support of one attitude or another in relation to the closing hours, but we must take the outlook of the average man. No responsible body in Ireland has asked for this Bill in its present form. There has been no public outcry against the licensing laws as we know them at present. Compare the example we have of the outcry of the public clamouring for a revision of our road traffic laws. We have not that kind of clamour or outcry in respect of the licensing laws.

MainHeading.P: Some people are critical of the existing licensing laws because they are not enforced in the same way everywhere. There are reasons for that and they were revealed in a statement made by a very prominent person some months ago. However, the fact remains that the law is there and can be enforced and, if it is enforced as it stands, I believe the general public will have no reason to complain.

Who wants this Bill as it stands? I cannot think of anyone. In his statement, the Minister indicated that he had an open mind on the matter and that he would be guided by the views expressed here in the House. I do not think he has heard any expression of satisfaction from the members of the Dáil who have spoken. We remember the abuses which resulted from prohibition in the United States, and the bootlegging which followed, caused by those who wanted to indulge in intoxicating liquor when they were deprived from having that amenity.

It was said by some of the interested organisations that this Bill proposes to give longer drinking hours. If it does propose to give longer drinking hours at the same time it seems to interfere with the traditional trading hours, and there will be an upset in the trade if the new arrangement of hours affects those. I am suggesting to the Minister that it is well within his powers to shelve this Bill now. It is not the first time a Bill was introduced in this House, debated, and dropped. For instance, there was the Valuations Bill, around 1945, and after a considerable amount of argument and debate that Bill was shelved and we have not heard about it since.

Speaker.hpid: Acting Chairman (Mr. Cunningham) Acting Chairman (Mr. Cunningham)
Speaker.P: These amendments deal with hours of closing on weekdays only. All we are discussing are hours of closing.

The case I am making in favour of my amendment is to show what I consider will be the consequences of the proposals contained in the Bill. I think I am right in discussing the contents of the Bill in relation to my amendment.
The House has agreed to discuss a number of amendments which deal with opening and closing hours on weekdays only.

In making the case in favour of an 11.30 p.m. closing hour I am asking the Minister to consider, having regard to the case that has been made by so many Deputies, whether in fact he should drop this Bill and then the question of hours will not arise. My proposing 11.30 p.m. was done on the assumption that the Minister will insist on putting through some kind of a licensing Bill. The traditional closing hour for many licensed premises outside Dublin City is 12 midnight, and this Bill proposes to put an end to the midnight closing.
It is not 12 o'clock. They are open to 3 or 4 o'clock in the morning.
I am not aware of places like that.
This Bill, I think, is trying to close them at 11.30 p.m.

I understand from the existing laws that the closing time is 12 o'clock. The premises which had the right to remain open until then will now find themselves in the position of being obliged to close at a much earlier hour but, if we look at the traditional closing hours in the city, they have been 10 p.m. in the winter and 10.30 p.m. in summer. I consider that a minor amendment of the existing laws would meet our modern needs, and I do not believe that this Bill will change the taste and habits of our people, and if the closing hour is changed, we must consider what the consequences will be.

MainHeading.P: The question of compensation has not been mentioned in the Bill. It proposes to put a number of people out of business, people who were engaged in trading up to 12 midnight. Then-premises were purchased at high cost, and costly alterations and improved amenities were provided in them. They were purchased on the basis of certified trading figures, the turnover figures between 10 p.m. and 12 midnight. They were the figures that mattered when such premises were changing hands. They are mostly situated in remote areas and they cannot expect to do any kind of early evening trading. There must be some population in the vicinity of licensed premises if it is to do substantial trade in the early hours of the evening and these premises I speak of will now find themselves on the same basis as City premises.

In other words, there will be a uniformity in the closing hours for licensed premises in these remote areas, where there is no local population, and for licensed premises in the city, and the premises in the remote areas cannot expect to do any kind of trade when the city premises are open at the same time. They cater for the person who wants to enjoy a drink later in the evening, for instance, for private social parties. They could avail of the amenities and the organised management of such premises which would not be available in shebeens or clubs to which people would be obliged to go if there is uniformity in the closing hour. These people I speak of can at present get a reliable drink in areas outside the city, but in the ordinary way, in a club or private dwelling house, they will not have drink served in an orderly way in which it can be diluted with the traditional minerals. You can have the example of the person who likes ginger ale to dilute his drink and it is not available. He has to take club lemon or club orange in that spirit, but in the well-organised premises they can have their drink properly served up to them.

This Bill is intended to stop late evening trading at premises which cater for this aspect of public enioyment. It is proposed that they will be closed at least one hour earlier than they had been closing but this one hour will represent approximately half of the traders' turnover and if they have to stop here in Dublin City and County—I am speaking of them mostly because the rural areas are able to speak for themselves—you will have a position where we shall have the carefree gaiety of Dublin city and county, the gaiety associated with this city and enjoyed by visitors and residents, destroyed.

You may have Dublin city by the change of these hours turned into a disreputable night club city. It is a very happy city as it is. The proposed hours will drive people into back rooms, sheds and various places, to bottle parties and the rest, where they can have drink instead of in an ordinary regular well-managed licensed premises. You will have them drinking in badly lighted smoke-filled dens of iniquity. That is the kind of life that you can expect in a city which is suddenly to have taken from it the kind of carefree gaiety associated with Dublin city and county, not alone in the minds of people in this country but also in the minds of people visiting the city. In fact the amenities available in the matter of the licensing hours are commented on very favourably by people who come here on holidays.

I consider that we should not fiddle with the hours characteristic of the evening life of Dublin City and County. The present arrangement caters for persons wishing to enjoy this late evening drinking. There is very little difference between it and the city closing hour but it does make all the difference to the social life of the people who enjoy these amenities. It is better to have this facility made available to them through well-controlled and well-managed services such as are provided by these very luxurious licensed premises right around Dublin city.

It is possible that illicit trading may result from the shortage of hours caused by the reduction proposed in this Bill. If we are to have illicit trading, we shall have the improper drinking arrangements which I mention —the bottle parties and the tragedies that follow them. I might mention in relation to this proposal that it will be equally difficult to enforce any laws provided in this new Bill as it has been to enforce the existing laws. You will always have the position where it will be difficult to enforce the laws but that is the very reason penalties are imposed if they are broken.

We have a situation which is not catered for here—the matter of closing time. Heavy penalties should be imposed on customers who refuse to leave licensed premises at closing time. It must be agreed that the customer who refuses to leave at closing time is just as guilty as the publican who encourages him to stay. Indeed, I do not know of any publicans who encourage their customers to stay after the closing hour. It is usually that they are persuaded because of their friendly attitude to the customers to allow them to stay on. I think there is a duty on customers who go into licensed premises to get out of them at closing time instead of putting the publican in the position that he almost has to use force to get them out. The present hours are reasonable. Why should we make closing time earlier? Surely it cannot be contended that 12 o'clock is a very late hour? We have the example of bottle parties carried on into the small hours of the morning and these are the parties that usually result in casualties.

I am proposing in this amendment, to meet the Minister to some extent, that 11.30 be the closing time. People have their radio programmes and television programmes going up to 11.30; the clubs have plenty of visitors. Listening to radio and television is part of the social life, which the people enjoy but, as I say, the closing time for these public services is 11.30. There is the other aspect of this closing time; I suppose I am entitled to mention it at this stage. It is proposed to give licences for dances up to 3 a.m. and reputable traders are to be deprived of their midnight closing time. They have a staff to employ, they have business premises to keep up and they have taxes to pay. These dances which are run only occasionally compared with licensed premises which must be run as a business regularly, are to be licensed until 3 a.m. It seems to be most unfair to the traders who are to be prevented from remaining open until midnight.

In support of the hours which I have mentioned I should like to quote a letter circulated by the Irish Country Vintners Association. I think the attitude of the trade to this matter is shown very clearly. It has been considered by the licensed traders of all Ireland, and as I say they reached a decision. The letter concerned, unfortunately, is undated. However it was circulated.

Speaker.P: Does this deal with the hours of opening and closing?
It does. This letter is from T.S. O'Dwyer, Honorary Secretary, Irish Country Vintners Association, Collinstown, Killucan, County Dublin. It reads:
“Dear Deputy—A general meeting was held in Dublin on January 12th attended by town and country traders from the Twenty-Six County areas outside the county boroughs. The following motions were passed:
(1) It was unanimously agreed to form the Irish County Vintners Association in the Twenty-Six Counties, outside the County Boroughs.

(2) While a great many publicans believed that 12 o'clock midnight was the most suitable hour all the year round, all associations and traders present unanimously agreed that there should be no earlier closing than 11.30 p.m. all the year round.

(3) As life in the various counties and rural districts is completely different to those in the city, it was unanimously agreed that there should be a later opening for the areas outside the County Boroughs. We feel, as the traditional closing hour is 12 midnight, any earlier closing will result in shebeens, drinking in crowded homes and private cars.

MainHeading.P: (4) In their official report of the recent Intoxicating Liquor Commission, all the commissioners (21) after hearing exhaustive evidence unanimously decided that the areas outside the County Boroughs should have 11.30 p.m. closing hours on weekdays all the year round.
I am,
Yours sincerely,
(Sgd.) T.S. O'Dwyer,
Hon. Secretary.
That letter is relevant because it deals with the areas to which I propose this amendment to apply, namely, Dublin County and the rural areas generally.

Another situation can arise if this change of hours is implemented. People who have been accustomed to visiting certain premises will be obliged to change their ways and go to other premises. Is it fair to interfere with the private lives of such people by forcing them away from one premises to another? This proposal of uniformity of hours was recommended on one occasion by a narrow majority of the Intoxicating Liquor Commission. That majority was secured because of some misunderstanding. It had the effect, in fact, of reversing a previous majority decision in favour of the differential which exists. Those traders who will be affected feel very badly about this proposal. They believe that the manner in which that narrow majority was secured should be fully and fairly investigated, especially in view of the earlier majority decision in favour of the differential.

These new hours will inevitably lead to abuses in relation to illicit drinking and to all the tragedies that follow from such drinking. It must be admitted that there is a high moral standard in regard to drinking in this country and that is due mainly to our well-managed and well-organised licensed premises. The same cannot be said with regard to private bottle parties, clubs and shebeens. It has been suggested that late evening drinking has caused road accidents. If one examines the statistics one will find that in the majority of accidents there was no question of any drink of any kind. In Northern Ireland there is an earlier closing hour than we have here. Out of a population of 1,000,000 there were 5,000 accidents in one year. In the same year, out of a population of close on 3,000,000 we had only 4,000 accidents. It is quite obvious that the advantage lies on the side of the Republic as compared with Northern Ireland. Again, the time at which most accidents occur is between 6 o'clock and 9 o'clock in the evening. That would not seem to bear out the argument that drink is an important single cause of accidents.

Speaker.P: The Deputy should not be throwing allegations around like this. He should come out in the open. If he has something to say, let him say it. I will not accept a statement, no matter how important the person who makes it, unless it is founded on fact.
